title: Auditing African Proposals, by WADA
description: Difficulty in auditing proposals in a growing community means scalability is affected

f6_assessments.q0: This is a good proposal to leverage the African community to audit African based proposals by a team already involved in reporting on currently funded projects. The big question is how will this scale. How many projects for how long will the requested funding allow auditing?
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers have been invovled in reporting on funded projects and thus have the ability to do thuis type of work. The plan however lacks information on how much auditing will be able do be done with the requested funding? How will it scale, how long will it run for. Perhaps they should be aiming to work with proposers to embed common standards for into the proposals to streamline auditability?
f6_assessments.q2: Whilst it will be easy to audit progress in terms of the hiring of CA's to do auditing, what really matters in this challenge is the auditing of the funded projects. They have set a success metric as the number of projects audited, but how many audits on how many proposals do they expect to be able to conduct for the requested funding? How does that compare to the number of African projects expected top be funded over the same time period?

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal does make great points about how it intends to support an auditing-based system for proposals, but it is limited in scope for only West African proposals.  This would limit the effectiveness of the auditing program to a small subset for Catalyst and could potentially cause differing metrics or standards of success across global proposals and West African ones.
f6_assessments.q1: The WADA team and the proposer have had many successful catalyst proposals in the past and have a solid team of people that they could rely on accomplishing the goals of the proposal.  The proposal is very human-intensive which is shown in the team members needed and the amount requested, would require more overhead to meet the goals described. A doubt about the proposal being implemented successfully is the ability to scale with a lot of the metrics/reporting seemingly done through personal data scraping in regards to getting information on future projects.
f6_assessments.q2: There is a plan for continuous improvement and guidelines on how to establish cadence for the team to ensure quality along the way.  The roadmap seems to address the requirement, with only hiring for the team to be the only area that would contain any unknowns.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal speaks about taking over the auditing function from IOG for auditing 'African Proposals'. It is unclear whether this refers to the proposals submitted un the 'Grow Africa, Grow Cardano' challenge or otherwise any proposal referring to Africa. The proposer fails to define how these 'auditors' will be chosen and who will pick them. It is unclear how any results such as data, reports, articles and videos will be shared with the community in general. 
Only $12,000 is being allocated to audit fees and no indication to how many proposals will be assessed and what material will be produced by the assessors.
f6_assessments.q1:
While WADA is an established community, although in its nascent stages, it is unclear whether they hold the necessary skills, competency or co-ordination to take up the auditing procedure of winning proposals relating to Africa. 
Certainly, upon reviewing the proposal submitted, I cannot say that I feel particularly confident in the team. The proposal lacks various details in various areas as described below. It is formulated as an idea with many vague terms and goals rather than a meticulous and cohesive plan. Finally, given what the proposal aim to accomplish, it seems unlike that it has been adequately budgeted or that the budget requested will see the project through.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal itself is very brief and lacks detail. WADA seems to indicate that everything will be kept in-house and in collaboration with partner https://www.blockchainedu.org/. No information is given on the recruitment process for auditors and whether the WADA network and its partner has enough competent human resources to take on both the task of recruitment and that of assessment of proposals. 
Secondly,  the proposal seems to cover 3 months, "create a 3-month auditing program where auditors will be tasked with creating bi-monthly reports, articles and videos on their assigned proposals.". Does this mean that the proposal is talking about the upcoming funds? Shouldn't the auditing program be aligned with the funds? 
3 of 4 of the goals under the impact section refer to 'increased visibility', 'stream of updates' and 'improved tracking of performance metrics'. No further info is given on this and it is unclear how these will be reached or what they mean exactly.
Another goal in to set an auditing process and auditing framework within 30 days. This very important as the assessment would have to follow this process and abide by the framework. No indication of what the framework or process will include was given. No information about the skills of people who would come up with this framework and process was shared. 
It speaks about a 3month auditing program but later there is written that after 90 days, in Fund 7, the proposals will be audited until their completion. I struggle to understand the plan and how the budget of 12,000 to audit team fees shall suffice and how they have been worked out.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal clearly meets the brief. It is good that it has a certain "trial period" baked in. The learning points from this can then be applied to a full-fledged ongoing auditing process. The only thing I'm not certain about is the African approach. Instead of geographic focus, would it be better that there were audit teams focused on type of challenges (infrastructure, dApps, marketing & outreach etc)? On the other hand, it can be justified to use this approach to ensure quality results. Just be careful not to create walled gardens. Furthermore, I like it that there's a certain marketing angle to the proposal. It's not just "boring bureaucracy" but aims to increase the visibility of the funded projects.
f6_assessments.q1: Josh and WADA are a reliable, professional and well-coordinated team. There is no doubt they can pull this off. If the geographic focus is chosen, then cities / countries might need their own coordinators in time to come but that might already be out of the scope of this proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: I don't know if bi-weekly refers to 1) "occurring every two months" or 2) "occurring twice a month" (guessing the latter). Apart from that I couldn't find any holes in the proposal. Perhaps setting goals for each of the metrics would make it even better but all in all it is a solid approach and deserves to be funded as is.

f6_assessments.q0: With 54 countries in Africa, the idea of a West African gatekeeper could lead to the exclusion of ideas from North, Central, East and South African Nations. This does not align with the campaign brief. The proposal end goal, to bring more funding towards African proposals, is good. But No plan is given on how centralizing a decentralized idea will benefit "Africa".
f6_assessments.q1: There is no evidence of  relevant skills and experience needed to implement the proposal. WADA alliance is not shown to have any auditing experience. There is no evidence of the type and number of team members required to implement the proposal. There is no budget outline, implementation plan or reason $23000 would be required. Information on how Auditing African Proposals would be built, and what technical / ethical aspects like architecture, language and technology would be used for implementation is missing.
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap, budget breakdown and key metrics are incomplete. An incomplete audit of this proposal does not bode well for an auditing endeavor. Percentages of proposals audited are given, but there is no indication of where these proposals are to come from, or plan on where to find the auditors themselves. It would be tough for a voter to keep up with the success of this proposal.
